results.title: Modulations
results.creator_credit: Judith Klein, Pierre Moretti and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film of playful observation, without commentary, catching in a few simple animated line drawings the image people project of themselves in the way they dress or move. Different types of people - plump dowager, curvaceous dancer, kilted Scot, ancient Egyptian - all make their bid for attention, metamorphosing one from the other in surprising ways. Music by Gordon Fleming, Herbert Spanier, Michel Donato and Eric MacDonald. Camera by Pierre Provost.

results.title: Modra
results.brief_description: In Tony Modra’s first senior year, 1992, Modra kicked 22 goals in only 8 games. This statistic was to belie his future goal kicking achievements in an impressive 1993 season which earned him the reputation of Crow spearhead as he went on goal spree after goal spree. Breaking all existing Crow records, Modra started the season in a blaze of glory and marched towards the club’s first 100 goal haul. Along the way he captivated supporters with daring leads, pin point accuracy and impressive aerial displays. 1993 was Tony Modra’s season.

results.title: Material matters
results.creator_credit: R I C H Warren, Sydney Sharples, Ralph May, Anvil Films and British Productivity Council
results.brief_description: Britain’s economy today rests largely upon its manufacturing industries. It is therefore essential that maximum use be made of local and imported raw materials. In Britain, waste causes a loss of hundreds of millions of pounds each year. Coal is the most wasted commodity of all - inefficient boilers, factory equipment and old-fashioned household grates waste as much as half the total coal produced in Britain each year. Within ten years, at this rate, Britain could not maintain enough coal supplies to meet the demand. Factories must keep down to a minimum the number of waste articles, for instance, there is more often than not unnecessary waste from both metal and plastic pressing, spray-painting etc. More economical and time-saving methods are required in the manufacture of parts. The film draws attention to the small innocuous wastes which usually go unnoticed. It is these wastes that add up to a national bill which Britain cannot afford.

results.title: Once upon Australia. River red
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Hilligoss, Klaus Toft and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: ‘Once upon Australia’ examines our dinosaur past, vividly recreating giant goannas and marsupials using animation. This is a world where humans have little or no part. ‘River Red’ profiles the natural environment of one of Australia’s best known trees, the River Red Gum.

results.title: Modern times
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Graeme Isaac, Film Australia and Mayfan
results.brief_description: An affectionate portrait of Port Pirie, the South Australian port and smelting town in which filmmaker, Graham Chase, grew up in the ‘50s and ‘60s. This is not merely a sentimental return to the long distant past. Rather, “Modern Times” presents an intimate insight into contemporary survival in an industrial town in decline, a story told with a mixture of empathy, scepticism and humour. Through the eyes of the “mates” who stayed behind in the town Graham Chase left, we receive a vivid picture of a small community facing an uncertain future as it struggles with new industries, the deadly legacy of lead pollution from the smelters and limited employment prospects.

results.title: Mastitus: disease of the udder
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Cherry, Lawrence Cherry and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An account of the causes, symptoms, prevention and cure of three types of mastitis in cattle: Acute, chronic and summer. The film illustrates common practices that contribute to the spread of the disease and demonstrates practical tests and treatment. The advantages of veterinary and clinical analysis and treatment are stressed.

results.title: One and a half dreams
results.creator_credit: George W. Frayne and Walter Rothschild Enterprises
results.brief_description: Introduces the work of the UN Development Program, initially contrasting the childhoods of a US astronaut and a boy in a developing country. Shows something of this program’s involvement in a number of countries and specificlaly looks at an agricultural training program in one developing country. Representatives of this project describe its organisation, function and prospects.

results.title: One a.m.
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin, Henry P. Caulfield, Lone Star Corporation and Van Beuren Corporation
results.brief_description: Charlie Chaplin at his slapstick best in the role of a drunk who unable to find his house keys climbs in through the window and ends up in a series of comic situations and confrontations. Cast also includes Albert Austin. No dialogue, music only.

results.title: Once were warriors
results.creator_credit: Lee Tamahori, Robin Scholes, Avalon Studios, Communicado, New Zealand Film Commission and New Zealand On Air
results.brief_description: Based on Alan Duff’s controversial best seller, “Once Were Warriors” is an intense and powerful film that leaves audiences stunned with its uncompromising insight into the strength of Maori culture in the face of degrading urban ghettos and devastating family violence. Jake (Temuera Morrison) and Beth (Rena Owen) have been married 18 years and she still finds him irresistible. Jake is a muscular, handsome man who exudes an explosive sexual energy but spends most of the time at the pub, often proving his masculinity with his fists and regularly exploding into rages that leave terrible scars on Beth and their family.
